when you build a recommendation engine one of the complex parts is there's no
one algorithm that fits all custom data use cases what you're typically going to

works and that's a lot of heavy lifting so we're good to thinking how can we
make this easier for you with no machine learning knowledge so this is how Amazon
personalized works we'll all we do is we ask you to provide two or three pieces of information so we
ask you to provide an activity stream so who interacted with what product so this
could be purchasing it could be perhaps borrowing library books as the product
is the library book it could be interacting with forms on your website who's downloaded which

demographic information about the users who are interacting with those products that can help us actually produce even
better recommendations by finding like a customers that's all you need to provide
personalized takes that in it puts that data in the format it needs for each of its machine learning algorithms and it

point which you can make API calls against so when you've got users returning and you know perhaps borrowing

at Amazon we've been doing supply chain forecasting for many many years we've

shelf if you forecast too high then you're going to end up with uncertain products and wastage if you're
forecasting staff levels required then you're going to end up with you know too many staff but if you forecast too low
then you're going to end up with dissatisfied customers or citizens as you are unable to fulfill their needs an
additional problem with forecasts is sometimes it's not just one data series sometimes there's a whole lot of related
data series that impact what you're forecasting on so let's say you're predicting the output of a solar panel
that could pretend on that could depend on the temperature of the day could depend on cloud cover if you're
predicting how customers or citizens are going to interact with your products it might depend on whether you've done a
marketing campaign or whether your competitors are doing marketing campaigns so there's going to be some
related time series you need to build in additionally to this let's say you're predicting the power usage of individual
customers need we're not just gonna build a model for 1 meter you need a model that can apply
and generalize over hundreds of thousands of you uses power meters and
for this reason forecasting is quite difficult and that's why we wanted to make it really easy for you with the
Amazon forecast service so really similar to personalized we just asked
you to provide your data so your historical data so let's say it was power meters provide the time series
data for those power meters over their historical usage or if it was staffing
levels providing the history of what staffing levels you needed then provide
some related data so if you find that the weather impacts your forecast then
provide the historical weather and the forecast for the weather moving forwards through the period you want to forecast
on and any other related time series data forecast we'll take your data in it
